title: How to Drink Mirto

steps.headline: Order mirto rosso to enjoy a sweet version of this popular liqueur.
steps.description: When you’re out eating a meal in Sardinia, it’s common to be offered an after-dinner drink. When asked if you’d like a glass of mirto, ask for mirto rosso to get Sardinia’s sweet, purple-hued berry liqueur. This version of mirto is made from the blue berries of the myrtle plant.

steps.headline: Pick mirto bianco if you like herby botanicals and a hint of sweetness.
steps.description: Made from the white berries of the myrtle plant, mirto bianco is less sweet that mirto rosso, though there is still an underlying sweetness from the berries and added sugar. If you enjoy gin, you may appreciate this version of mirto. Some bottles of mirto bianco are made from the leaves of the myrtle plant rather than the berries.Tip: If you’re in Sardinia and find that you love mirto, bring a bottle home with you! It can be hard to find outside of the island itself.

steps.headline: Serve small glasses of chilled mirto as an after-dinner drink.
steps.description: If you’re lucky enough to have a bottle of mirto at home, enjoy it on your own after a delicious meal or offer it to guests as you relax and talk. Chill small glasses in the freezer and pour 2 to 3 ounces (57 to 85 g) of liqueur into each glass once you’re ready to serve it. Mirto is best enjoyed chilled—you could store your bottle in the fridge or freezer to make sure it’s always ready when you want it. If you’re in a pinch, add 2 to 3 ounces (57 to 85 g) of mirto to a cocktail shaker filled with ice. Shake it until the liquid is completely cool, then strain it into a glass.

steps.headline: Sip mirto slowly to enjoy its flavors rather than taking it as a shot.
steps.description: Enjoy small sips of your drink over the course of an hour or two as you enjoy the company of your family and friends. Think of it as an accompaniment to your conversation—the longer you drink, the longer you’ll be able to sit with your guests. Mirto is about 50-60% alcohol by volume, so it’s a pretty potent drink. Many versions are cut with filtered water to reduce the alcohol content to 30%, but you should still exercise caution when drinking.

steps.headline: Muddle the thyme and bitters together in a shaker glass.
steps.description: Take 3 sprigs of thyme and put them in the bottom of a shaker glass, then add 3 dashes of bitters. Use a muddler to mash them together and release the thyme’s aromatics. Muddling the thyme will help its flavors infuse into the liquor much more easily. Bitters are made from aromatic botanicals and create extra depth in a cocktail.

steps.headline: Measure the whiskey and mirto into the shaker and stir.
steps.description: Pour 1.5 ounces (43 g) of rye whiskey and 1 ounce (28 g) of mirto into the shaker glass along with the muddled thyme and bitters. Use a spoon to mix them, or top the shaker and give it a few shakes up and down. If you don’t have rye whiskey, substitute bourbon in its place.All About Mirto: Mirto is a fruity liqueur that comes from the island of Sardinia off the coast of Italy. It’s made from the berries of the mirto plant and has a purple-red hue. It tastes of herbs, berries, oranges, and warm spices, like cinnamon and clove. It’s traditionally drank chilled as an after-dinner digestif, though it can easily be added to many different cocktails.

steps.headline: Strain the contents of the shaker into a rocks glass filled with ice.
steps.description: If your shaker glass has a built-in strainer, use that. If not, use a strainer with fine mesh to catch the remnants of the thyme sprigs so they don’t end up in your cocktail. If you don’t have a rocks glass, any kind will do! Just make sure to fill it with ice so that your drink will stay chilled.

steps.headline: Add the ginger beer and garnish the glass with thyme and a lemon rind.
steps.description: Top off your glass with 1 ounce (28 g) of ginger beer and use a knife to cut off a small bit of lemon rind. If you want, add a few sprigs of fresh thyme for a nice finishing effect. There are both alcoholic and non-alcoholic ginger beers. If you use an alcoholic one, just be aware of the extra alcohol it adds to the drink if you’re planning on driving later.

methods.name: Using Mirto in Your Favorite Cocktails

steps.headline: Create a mirto martini with mirto, lime, orange, and fresh berries.
steps.description: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice, then pour in 1 ounce (28 g) of orange-flavored vodka, ⁄4 ounce (21 g) of mirto, ⁄4 ounce (21 g) of fresh lime juice, ⁄2 ounce (14 g) of triple sec, and ⁄4 ounce (7.1 g) of simple syrup. Shake the contents to mix and chill them, then strain the drink into a martini glass. Skewer 3-4 blueberries to garnish the glass. If you don’t have blueberries, you could use any other kind of berry. If you don’t have fresh lime juice, bottled will work just fine.

steps.headline: Make a refreshing mirto and tonic for a unique twist on this classic cocktail.
steps.description: Put a rocks glass into the freezer for about 20 minutes before you make your drink. Once it’s ready, fill it with ice. Pour 2 ounces (57 g) of gin over the ice, fill the glass the rest of the way with tonic water, and squeeze in some fresh lime juice. Give your drink a quick stir and enjoy. Add a sprig of rosemary for a fragrant garnish to your cocktail.

steps.headline: Enjoy a mirto-infused rum fizz for an enticingly light and bright drink.
steps.description: Muddle 1 teaspoon (4 grams) of sugar and 6-7 blueberries in a cocktail shaker. Add 2 ounces (57 g) of white rum, 1 ounce (28 g) of freshly-squeezed lemon juice, and 1 ounce (28 g) of mirto. Shake everything together, fill a tall glass with ice, and pour the shaker contents in. Top off the drink with club soda and enjoy. To infuse your drink with an extra essence, use flavored sparkling water. Cucumber would be a different but refreshing choice, or a fruit-flavored sparkling water would enhance the drink even more.

steps.headline: Swap out vermouth for mirto give your Manhattan a little extra spice.
steps.description: Fill a shaker glass with ice and add 2 ounces (57 g) of whiskey, ⁄2 ounce (14 g) of mirto, and a dash of bitters. Stir the liquids together until they’re chilled, and then strain the contents into a cocktail glass. Manhattans are normally garnished with a maraschino cherry, but you could switch that out for a plump blackberry or blueberry to give your drink an extra twist. To keep your Manhattan chilled for longer, put the cocktail glass into the freezer an hour or so before you plan on making your drink.

steps.headline: Make a sparkling cocktail with muddled mint, cava, and mirto.
steps.description: Muddle 2-3 mint leaves and add them to the bottom of a champagne glass. Fill the glass 2/3 of the way full with cava, and then top it off with 1 ounce (28 g) of mirto. If you don’t have cava, champagne can be used to the same effect. If you want your drink to be sweeter, add 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of simple syrup.

steps.headline: Mix a blackberry mirto bramble for a stimulating summer treat.
steps.description: Shake together 2 ounces (57 g) of gin, ⁄2 ounce (14 g) of lemon juice, 1 ounce (28 g) of blackberry simple syrup, and 1 ounce (28 g) of mirto. Strain the drink into a chilled, ice-filled rocks glass and garnish it with a wedge of lemon and 2-3 fresh blackberries. If you don’t like gin, vodka can be substituted in its place.Blackberry Simple Syrup: Heat 1 cup (240 mL) of water, 1/2 cup (104 grams) of sugar, and 1/2 cup (72 grams) of fresh blackberries in a small saucepan until it boils and the sugar dissolves. Remove the pan from the heat and let the syrup steep for 20 minutes. Puree the blackberries and syrup, then strain it into a glass container to remove the seeds.
